channel.description: Hire Raquel Moss, experienced full-stack web developer

item.title: What is State? Why do I need to manage it?
item.description: Read my thoughts on state over at egghead

item.title: Better Code Review
item.description: I recently read an article by Max Bittker called "How to Review Code You Don't Understand" , and it got me to thinking about times when I've been tasked with doing just that. One of the troubles I have with code review is understanding the context…

item.title: Creating a Welcoming Space for Beginners
item.description: Before I became a programmer, I was a teacher. For the most part, I taught academic English to speakers of other languages at a University. Although I’ve switched careers, I find that my teaching experience becomes applicable very frequently in my…

item.title: Becoming Comfortable with Being Uncomfortable
item.description: Last time I blogged I wrote about how programming was something that comes unnaturally to me. The post seemed to resonate with lots of people — several reached out to share their own experiences, which was extremely encouraging. If you ever want to…

item.title: Continuing your learning as a post-beginner programmer (part 1)
item.description: If you’re anything like me, your process for learning something new — say, a javascript framework, a design pattern, or a language — looks something like this: Read the documentation, check out a basic tutorial, and get Hello World up and running…

item.title: Becoming a better developer, day by day
item.description: I’ve been experiencing a lot of anxiety lately about my life as a developer. The narrative will be familiar to anyone who’s ever pursued programming in a meaningful way; even if you write code every day, and learn something new every day, the nagging…

item.title: Continuing your learning as a post-beginner programmer (part 3)
item.description: Missed Part 1 ? Or Part 2 ? Read them for more strategies on how to continue your learning as a programmer. Hands up if this has ever happened to you: You’ve been learning something new, and maybe working with it for a few weeks. You run into a…

item.title: Continuing your learning as a post-beginner programmer (part 2)
item.description: Read part one here Read part three here In part one of this series, I talked about a few different things you can do to continue your learning as a post-beginner programmer. In this part, I’ll be talking about a few more strategies to help your…

item.title: Review: Scalable and Modular Architecture for CSS by Jonathan Snook
item.description: Over the last year I’ve become increasingly frustrated with CSS. I used to be its champion; when people moaned about how touchy and picky CSS is, I told them “It’s really not that hard! You probably have a specificity problem, let’s take a look…

item.title: Unnatural
item.description: For most of my life I’ve avoided doing things that don’t come naturally to me. I quit maths at school after gaining University Entrance, because I was only getting Merits rather than Excellences. Same for all the sciences. I wasn’t any good at…

item.title: On Imposter Syndrome and Learning
item.description: Maturation has been on my mind a lot lately. No surprise, I suppose, as I’m a 23-year-old introvert. I spend a lot of time inside my own mind, which can be wonderful, terrifying, and confusing. Occasionally, but with increasing frequency (relative to…
